text: This Act may be cited as the Public Order Act.

text: In this Act, except where the context otherwise requires—
label: not_provision
explanation: This is an introductory phrase indicating definitions or exceptions may follow, but it does not establish a standalone legal rule or obligation.

text: "Cabinet Secretary" means the Cabinet Secretary for the time being responsible for the administration;
label: not_provision
explanation: This paragraph provides a definition rather than establishing a legal rule, right, obligation, restriction, or process.

text: "excluded meeting" means— (a) any meeting convened and held exclusively for the lawful purposes of any public body; or (b) any meeting of the members of any registered organisation, whether corporate or unincorporate, convened in accordance with the constitution of the organisation and held exclusively for the lawful purposes of that organisation; (c) any meeting of the members of any trade union convened and held exclusively for the lawful purposes of that trade union; (d) any meeting convened and held exclusively for social, cultural, charitable, educational, commercial or industrial purposes; (e) any meeting of the organs of a political party, convened in accordance with the constitution of the party and held exclusively to discuss the affairs of the party; (f) impromptu "meet-the-people" tours by Members of Parliament and councillors;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines 'excluded meeting' by listing specific types of meetings that qualify, establishing a legal definition and criteria for exclusion.

text: "hours of darkness" means the hours between half-past six in the evening and half-past six on the following morning;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a specific term ('hours of darkness') used within the legal document, establishing a clear rule for interpretation and application.

text: "hours of daylight" means the hours between half-past six in the morning and half-past six in the evening;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term, which is a common feature of legal provisions. It establishes a specific meaning for 'hours of daylight' that can be enforced or referenced in the context of the document.

text: "meeting" means any gathering of persons (not being an excluded meeting) convened and held for any purpose, including any political purpose;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('meeting') for the purposes of the legal document, establishing a rule for interpretation.

text: "offensive weapon" means any article made or adapted for use for causing injury to the person, or intended by the person having it in his possession or under his control for such use;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('offensive weapon') in a way that establishes a legal rule or standard, which is enforceable and actionable in legal contexts.

text: "political organisation" means any organisation which either has among its objects any political purpose or pursues any political purpose;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term, which is a key part of establishing legal rules and obligations, making it a provision.

text: "premises" includes any land, any building and any other place whatsoever;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('premises') used in the legal document, establishing a legal understanding of what is included under that term. Definitions are considered provisions as they set enforceable parameters for interpretation.

text: "private premises" means premises which are not public places;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term, which is a common type of legal provision as it establishes the meaning of 'private premises' within the context of the document.

text: "public gathering" means a public meeting, a public procession, and any other meeting, gathering or concourse of ten or more persons in any public place;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('public gathering') used within the legal document, establishing a specific legal meaning that can be enforced or referenced in legal contexts.

text: "public meeting" means any meeting held or to be held in a public place, and any meeting which the public or any section of the public or more than fifty persons are or are to be permitted to attend whether on payment or otherwise;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term used within the legal document, establishing a specific meaning for 'public meeting,' which is essential for interpreting and applying the law.

text: "public place" means any place to which for the time being the public or any section of the public are entitled or permitted to have access whether on payment or otherwise, and, in relation to any meeting to be held in the future, includes any place which will, on the occasion and for the purposes of such meeting, be a public place;
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines the term 'public place' for legal purposes, establishing a rule for interpretation within the document.

text: "public procession" means any procession in, to or from a public place;
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a definition, not a standalone legal provision. It clarifies a term used in the document but does not establish a rule or obligation.

text: "regulating officer" means the officer-in-charge of the police station in the area in which a proposed public meeting is proposed to be held, or in the case of a public procession, the police officer-in-charge of the police station in the area in which the procession is proposed to start and to end;
label: not_provision
explanation: This paragraph provides a definition rather than establishing a legal rule, right, obligation, restriction, or process.

text: "school" means any premises or any part of any premises where persons are habitually or for the time being taught, whether in one class or more.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines the term 'school' for the purposes of the legal document, establishing a legal definition that can be enforced or referenced in the application of the law.

label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation of amendments and legal references, not a standalone legal provision.

text: PART II – QUASI-MILITARY ORGANISATIONS AND POLITICAL UNIFORMS
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a part heading, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 3.  Prohibition of organisations equipped to usurp functions of police, etc. (1)  If the members or adherents of any association of persons, whether incorporated or not, are— (a) organised or trained or equipped for the purpose of enabling them to be employed in usurping the functions of the police or of the Kenya Defence Forces; or (b) organised and trained or organised and equipped either for the purpose of enabling them to be employed for the use or display of physical force in promoting any political object, or in such manner as to arouse reasonable apprehension that they are organised and either trained or equipped for that purpose, then any member or adherent of such association shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding one hundred thousand shillings or imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years, or to both such fine and such imprisonment, and any person who promotes or conspires with another to promote or who takes part in the control or management of the association, or in so organising or training or equipping as aforesaid any member or adherent thereof, shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine of two thousand shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three years, or to both such fine and such imprisonment:
label: provision
explanation: The paragraph establishes a legal rule prohibiting certain associations from organizing or training members to usurp police or military functions, and it specifies penalties for violations, making it an enforceable legal provision.

text: Provided that in any proceedings against a person charged with the offence of taking part in the control or management of such an association as aforesaid it shall be a defence to that charge to prove that he neither consented to nor connived at the organisation, training or equipment of members or adherents of the association in contravention of the provisions of this section.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal defense for a person charged with a specific offense, outlining the conditions under which the defense is applicable. It contains enforceable content related to legal proceedings.

text: (2)  No prosecution under this section shall be instituted without the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.
label: provision
explanation: This sentence establishes a legal requirement that no prosecution can be initiated without the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions, making it an enforceable rule.

text: (3)  If, upon application being made by the Attorney-General, it appears to the High Court that any association is an association of which members or adherents are organised, trained or equipped in contravention of the provisions of this section, the Court may make such order as appears necessary to prevent any disposition without the leave of the Court of property held by or for the association, and may direct an inquiry and report to be made as to any such property as aforesaid and as to the affairs of the association, and may make such further orders as appear to the Court to be just and equitable for the application of such property in or towards the discharge of the liabilities of the association lawfully incurred before the date of the application or since that date with the approval of the Court, in or towards repayment of moneys to persons who became subscribers or contributors to the association in good faith and without knowledge of any such contravention as aforesaid, and in or towards any costs incurred in connexion with any such inquiry and report as aforesaid or in winding up or dissolving the association, and may order that any property which is not directed by the Court to be so applied as aforesaid shall be forfeited.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process and the powers of the High Court regarding associations that contravene certain provisions. It outlines enforceable actions the Court may take, such as making orders about property and directing inquiries.

text: (4)  In any criminal or civil proceedings under this section, proof of things done or of words written, spoken or published (whether or not in the presence of any party to the proceedings) by any person taking part in the control or management of an association or in organising, training or equipping members or adherents of an association shall be admissible as evidence of the purposes for which, or the manner in which, members or adherents of the association (whether those persons or others) were organised, or trained or equipped.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a rule regarding the admissibility of evidence in legal proceedings, specifically related to actions or words by individuals involved with an association. It outlines how such evidence can be used to demonstrate the purposes or methods of the association, making it an enforceable legal provision.

text: (5)  If a judge of the High Court or magistrate is satisfied by information on oath that there is reasonable ground for suspecting that an offence under this section has been committed, and that evidence of the commission thereof is to be found at any premises or place specified in the information, he may, on an application made by a police officer of a rank not lower than that of Inspector, grant a search warrant authorising any such police officer named in the warrant together with any other persons named in the warrant and any other police officers to enter the premises or place at any time within one month from the date of the warrant, if necessary by force, and to search the premises or place and every person found therein, and seize anything found on the premises or place or on any such person which the officer has reasonable ground for suspecting to be evidence of the commission of such an offence as aforesaid:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for obtaining a search warrant, detailing the conditions under which it can be granted and the authority it provides to police officers.

text: Provided that no woman shall, in pursuance of a warrant issued under this subsection, be searched except by a woman.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the conditions under which a woman can be searched, specifying that it must be done by another woman. It is enforceable and actionable.

text: (6)  Nothing in this section shall be construed as prohibiting the employment of a reasonable number of persons as stewards to assist in the preservation of order at any public meeting held upon private premises, or the making of arrangements for that purpose or the instruction of the persons to be so employed in their lawful duties as such stewards, or their being furnished with badges or other distinguishing signs.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the employment of stewards at public meetings on private premises, detailing what is not prohibited by the section.

label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation and reference to legal amendments and schedules, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 4.  Prohibition of uniforms, etc., in connexion with political objects (1)  The Cabinet Secretary may from time to time by order prohibit the wearing in public places or at public meetings of— (a) repealed by Act No. 10 of 1997, Sch.; (b) any uniform, distinctive dress or emblem by members or adherents of any organisation or association specified or described in the order, whether incorporated or not— (i) when, in the opinion of the Cabinet Secretary, members of that organisation or association are organised or trained or equipped for the purpose of enabling them to be employed in usurping the functions of the police or of the Defence Forces; or (ii) when, in the opinion of the Cabinet Secretary, members of that organisation or association are organised or trained or equipped for the purpose of enabling them to be employed for the use or display of physical force in promoting any political or other object or in such a manner as to arouse reasonable apprehension that they are organised or trained or equipped for that purpose.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by granting the Cabinet Secretary the authority to prohibit certain actions related to political uniforms, which is enforceable and actionable.

text: (2)  Any person who contravenes the provisions of any order made under subsection (1) of this section shall be guilty of an offence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by stating that contravening certain provisions constitutes an offence, which is enforceable.

label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation and reference to legislative amendments and schedules, not a standalone legal provision.

text: PART III – PUBLIC GATHERINGS
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a part heading and does not contain enforceable or actionable content.

text: 5.  Regulation of Public meeting and Processions (1)  No person shall hold a public meeting or a public procession except in accordance with the provisions of this section.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by stating that public meetings or processions must comply with specific provisions, making it enforceable.

text: (2)  Any person intending to convene a public meeting or a public procession shall notify the regulating officer of such intent at least three days but not more than fourteen days before the proposed date of the public meeting or procession.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation for individuals to notify a regulating officer within a specific timeframe before convening a public meeting or procession.

text: (3)  A notice under subsection (2) shall be in the prescribed form and shall specify— (a) the full names and physical address of the organiser of the proposed public meeting or public procession; (b) the proposed date of the meeting or procession and the time thereof which shall be between six o’clock in the morning and six o’clock in the afternoon; (c) the proposed site of the public meeting or the proposed route in the case of a public procession.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes specific requirements for a notice related to public meetings or processions, detailing the form and content necessary for compliance.

text: (4)  Where, upon receipt of a notice under subsection (2), it is not possible to hold the proposed public meeting or public procession for the reason that notice of another public meeting or procession on the date, at the time and at the venue proposed has already been received by the regulating officer, the regulating officer shall forthwith notify the organiser.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process and obligation for the regulating officer to notify the organiser if a proposed public meeting or procession cannot be held due to a scheduling conflict.

text: (5)  The notification by the regulating officer under subsection (4) shall be in writing and shall be delivered to the organiser at the physical address specified pursuant to the provision of subsection (3).
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal requirement for the notification by the regulating officer to be in writing and delivered to a specified address, which is an enforceable obligation.

text: (6)  Where the regulating officer notifies the organiser of a public meeting or public procession in accordance with subsection (3) that it is not possible to hold the proposed meeting or procession, such public meeting or procession shall not be held on the date, at the time and venue proposed, but may, subject to this section, be held on such future date as the organiser may subsequently notify.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the conditions under which a public meeting or procession may be held, including the requirement for notification and potential rescheduling.

text: (7)  The organiser of every public meeting or public procession or his authorised agent shall be present throughout the meeting or procession and shall assist the police in the maintenance of peace and order at the meeting or procession.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes obligations for the organiser of a public meeting or procession, requiring their presence and cooperation with the police to maintain peace and order. It contains enforceable content.

text: (8)  The regulating officer or any police officer of or above the rank of inspector may stop or prevent the holding of— (a) any public meeting or public procession held contrary to the provisions of subsections (2) or (6); (b) any public gathering or other meeting or procession which, having regard to the rights and interests of the persons participating in such gathering, meeting or procession, there is clear, present or imminent danger of a breach of the peace or public order, and may, for any of the purposes aforesaid, give or issue such orders, including orders for the dispersal of the meeting, procession or gathering as are reasonable in the circumstances, having regard to the rights and freedoms of the persons in respect of whom such orders are issued and the rights and freedoms of others.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes the authority of certain officers to stop or prevent public meetings or processions under specific conditions, outlining enforceable actions and considerations.

text: (9)  Any person who neglects or refuses to obey any order given or issued under subsection (7) shall be guilty of an offence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation and specifies a consequence for non-compliance, making it an enforceable rule.

text: (10)  Any public meeting or public procession held contrary to the provisions of subsections (1) and (5) shall be deemed to be an unlawful assembly.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by defining certain public meetings or processions as unlawful assemblies if they contravene specific subsections.

text: (11)  Any person who takes part in any public meeting or public procession deemed to be an unlawful assembly under subsection (10), or holds, convenes or organises or is concerned in the holding, convening or organising of any such meeting or procession shall be guilty of the offence of taking part in an unlawful assembly under Chapter IX of the Penal Code and liable to imprisonment for one year.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule and specifies the offense and penalty for participating in or organizing an unlawful assembly.

text: (12)  The organiser of any excluded meeting may request the regulating officer that the police be present at such meeting to ensure the maintenance of peace and order.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal right for the organiser to request police presence at a meeting, which is enforceable and actionable.

text: (13)  A request under subsection (12) shall be in writing and shall be delivered to the regulating officer at least three days before the proposed date of the meeting.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a specific requirement for making a request, including the form (in writing) and the timeframe (at least three days before the meeting), which is enforceable.

text: (14)  The regulating officer shall keep a public register of all notices received under subsection (2).
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes an obligation for the regulating officer to maintain a public register, which is an enforceable action.

text: (15)  Any person may, during working hours, inspect the register kept under subsection (14).
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal right for any person to inspect the register during working hours, making it an enforceable rule.

text: [Act No. 10 of 1997, Sch.]
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation or reference to an act and schedule, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 6.  Prohibition of offensive weapons at public meetings and processions (1)  Any person who, while present at any public meeting or on the occasion of any public procession, has with him any offensive weapon, otherwise than in pursuance of lawful authority, shall be guilty of an offence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule prohibiting the possession of offensive weapons at public meetings or processions without lawful authority, and specifies that violation constitutes an offence.

text: (2)  For the purposes of this section, a person shall not be deemed to be acting in pursuance of lawful authority unless he is acting in his capacity as a police officer
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule defining when a person is considered to be acting under lawful authority, specifically in the capacity of a police officer.

text: or member of a fire brigade or otherwise in his capacity as a public officer or as a servant of a local authority.
label: not_provision
explanation: This text appears to be part of a larger sentence or clause, likely specifying exceptions or roles, but it does not independently establish a legal rule or obligation.

label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation indicating the act number and section, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 7.  Power to prohibit entertainments and sporting events (1)  If at any time it appears to the Inspector-General of National Police Service that serious public disorder is likely to arise at or on the occasion of any race- meeting, sporting event or other entertainment of any description, he may, by notice addressed to the promoter, organiser or manager thereof, prohibit the holding or continuance thereof in any area or place or on any particular day.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule granting the Inspector-General of National Police Service the authority to prohibit events if there is a likelihood of serious public disorder.

text: (2)  A notice under subsection (1) of this section shall be served on the person, or one of the persons if more than one, promoting, organising or managing the race-meeting, sporting event or entertainment.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation regarding the service of a notice to specific individuals involved in organizing an event, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (3)  If such race-meeting, sporting event or entertainment is held or continued in contravention of the terms of a notice issued under subsection (1) of this section, any person taking part in the promotion, organisation or management thereof shall be guilty of an offence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by stating that participating in the promotion, organization, or management of an event held in contravention of a notice is an offense.

text: (4)  Any police officer may give or issue such orders and use such force as may be necessary to prevent the holding or continuance of a race-meeting, sporting event or other entertainment the holding or continuance of which has been prohibited by a notice issued under subsection (1) of this section and to disperse any gathering of persons thereat.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes the authority of police officers to issue orders and use necessary force to prevent or disperse prohibited events, making it an enforceable legal rule.

text: (5)  Any person who neglects or refuses to obey any order given or issued under subsection (4) of this section shall be guilty of an offence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation and specifies a consequence for non-compliance, making it enforceable.

text: (6)  A certificate under the hand of the Inspector-General of the National Police Service, specifying the terms, and the date and manner of service, of a notice under this section, shall be prima facie evidence thereof in all legal proceedings.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the evidentiary status of a certificate issued by the Inspector-General of the National Police Service. It specifies that such a certificate is considered prima facie evidence in legal proceedings, which is an enforceable legal concept.

label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation and reference to legislative amendments and not a standalone legal provision.

text: PART IV – CURFEW ORDERS AND CURFEW RESTRICTION ORDERS
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a part heading and does not contain enforceable or actionable content.

text: 8.  Curfew orders (1)  The Cabinet Secretary, on the advice of the Inspector-General of the National Police Service may, if he considers it necessary in the interests of public order so to do, by order (hereinafter referred to as a curfew order) direct that, within such area and during such hours as may be specified in the curfew order, every person, or, as the case may be, every member of any class of persons specified in the curfew order, shall, except under and in accordance with the terms and conditions of a written permit granted by an authority or person specified in the curfew order, remain indoors in the premises at which he normally resides, or at such other premises as may be authorised by or under the curfew order. (2) (a) It shall be a condition of every permit granted under subsection (1) of this section that the holder thereof shall at all times while acting under the authority thereof during the hours of darkness carry a light visible at a distance of twenty-five feet. (b) Subject to paragraph (a) of this subsection, a permit under subsection (1) of this section may be granted subject to such conditions, to be specified in the permit, as the authority or person granting it may think fit.
label: provision
explanation: The paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the imposition of curfew orders, the conditions under which they can be issued, and the requirements for permits during such curfews. It outlines enforceable obligations and processes.

text: (3)  A curfew order shall be published in such manner as the authority making it may think sufficient to bring it to the notice of all persons affected thereby, and shall come into force on such day, being the day of or a day after the making thereof, as may be specified therein, and shall remain in force for the period specified therein or until earlier rescinded by the same authority or by the Cabinet Secretary as hereinafter provided:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the publication and enforcement of a curfew order, including how it comes into force and its duration.

text: Provided that no curfew order which imposes a curfew operating during more than ten consecutive hours of daylight shall remain in force for more than three days, and no curfew order which imposes a curfew operating during any lesser number of consecutive hours of daylight shall remain in force for more than seven days.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes specific limitations on the duration of curfew orders, making it an enforceable legal rule.

text: (4)  Deleted by Act No. 19 of 2014, s. 4(b).
label: not_provision
explanation: This text indicates a deletion and references an amendment, which is not a standalone legal provision.

text: (5)  The variation or rescission of a curfew order shall be published in like manner as that provided in subsection (3) of this section for the publication of a curfew order.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for the publication of variations or rescissions of a curfew order, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (6)  Any person who contravenes any of the provisions of a curfew order or any of the terms or conditions of a permit granted to him under subsection (1) of this section shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding ten thousand shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months, or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule and specifies penalties for contravening a curfew order or permit conditions, making it enforceable.

text: (7)  A certificate under the hand of the authority making, varying or rescinding a curfew order, specifying the terms, and the date and manner of publication, of such order, variation or rescission, shall be prima facie evidence thereof in all legal proceedings.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the evidentiary status of a certificate related to curfew orders in legal proceedings.

text: (8)  Any person who, without lawful excuse, carries or has in his possession, in any area in which a curfew order is in force and during the hours during which the curfew imposed thereby is operative, any offensive weapon shall be guilty of an offence:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by defining an offense related to carrying an offensive weapon during a curfew, thus making it enforceable.

text: Provided that no person shall be convicted of an offence under this section if he proves to the satisfaction of the Court that he carried or had in his possession the offensive weapon— (i) solely for domestic or defensive purposes within enclosed premises which he lawfully occupied or in which he was lawfully present; or (ii) with the authority of his employer and solely for domestic or defensive purposes within enclosed premises in the lawful occupation of his employer.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the conditions under which a person shall not be convicted of an offence related to possession of an offensive weapon. It specifies the circumstances that can be used as a defense in court, making it enforceable and actionable.

label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation of amendments and legal references, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 9.  Curfew restriction orders (1)  A police officer in charge of the police in a county or a police officer in charge of a police division may, if he considers it necessary in the interests of public order within the area of his responsibility so to do, by order (hereinafter referred to as a curfew restriction order) prohibit, during such hours as may be specified in the curfew restriction order, all persons, or, as the case may be, all members of any class of persons specified in the curfew restriction order, from entering, being or remaining, except under and in accordance with the terms and conditions of a written permit granted by an authority or person specified in the curfew restriction order, in or at any premises specified in the curfew restriction order:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule allowing police officers to issue curfew restriction orders under specific conditions, detailing the scope and enforcement of such orders.

text: Provided that no person shall, by or in pursuance of a curfew restriction order, be prohibited or prevented from entering, being or remaining in any premises at which he normally resides, or, during reasonable hours of business, work or employment, any premises at which he normally has his place of business, work or employment.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding exceptions to curfew restrictions, specifying rights related to residence and employment premises.

text: (2)  A permit under subsection (1) of this section may be granted subject to such conditions, to be specified in the permit, as the authority or person granting it may think fit.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the granting of permits, specifying that they may be subject to conditions determined by the granting authority.

text: (3)  A curfew restriction order shall be published in such manner as the authority making it may think sufficient to bring it to the notice of all persons affected thereby, and shall come into force on such day, being the day of or a day after the making thereof, as may be specified therein, and shall remain in force for such period, not exceeding twenty-eight days, as may be specified therein or until earlier rescinded by the same authority or by the Cabinet Secretary as hereinafter provided.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the publication, commencement, and duration of a curfew restriction order, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (4)  Every curfew restriction order shall, forthwith on its being made, be reported to the Inspector General of Police, and the Inspector General of Police may, if he thinks fit, vary or rescind the curfew restriction order.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation to report curfew restriction orders to the Inspector General of Police and grants the Inspector General the authority to vary or rescind such orders.

text: (5)  The variation or rescission of a curfew restriction order shall be published in like manner as that provided in subsection (3) of this section for the publication of a curfew restriction order.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for the publication of a variation or rescission of a curfew restriction order, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (6)  Any person who contravenes any of the provisions of a curfew restriction order or any of the terms or conditions of a permit granted to him under subsection (1) of this section shall be guilty of an offence and liable to a fine not exceeding ten thousand shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months, or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule by specifying the consequences for contravening a curfew restriction order or permit terms, including fines and imprisonment.

text: (7)  A certificate under the hand of the authority making, varying or rescinding a curfew restriction order, specifying the terms, and the date and manner of publication, of such order, variation or rescission, shall be prima facie evidence thereof in all legal proceedings.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the evidentiary status of a certificate related to curfew restriction orders in legal proceedings.

label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation and reference to amendments and legislative history, not a standalone legal provision.

explanation: This is a part heading and does not contain enforceable or actionable content.

text: PART VI – FURTHER PROVISIONS TO SAFEGUARD PUBLIC ORDER
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a part heading and does not contain enforceable or actionable content.

text: 11.  Possession of offensive weapon in public place (1)  Any person who, without lawful authority or reasonable excuse, the proof whereof shall lie on him, has with him in any street or public place any offensive weapon shall be guilty of an offence and liable to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or to a fine not exceeding one hundred thousand shillings, or to both such imprisonment and such fine.
label: provision
explanation: The paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the possession of offensive weapons in public places, specifying the offense and the penalties involved.

text: (2)  Where any person is convicted of an offence under subsection (1) of this section, the Court may make an order for the forfeiture of any weapon in respect of which the offence was committed.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the forfeiture of weapons upon conviction of an offence, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (3)  Every offence under this section shall be cognisable to the police.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the cognisability of offences by the police, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (4)  In this section, "offensive weapon" means any article made or adapted for use for causing injury to the person, or capable of being so used, or intended by the person having it with him for such use, and includes any panga, simi or similar weapon.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('offensive weapon') within the context of the legal document, establishing a legal rule about what constitutes an 'offensive weapon.' This definition is enforceable and actionable.

text: (5) (a) This section shall apply to such areas, and during such hours, as the Cabinet Secretary may, by notice in the Gazette, declare. (b) A notice under this section may apply the section during different hours in respect of different areas.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the application of a section to certain areas and times, as determined by the Cabinet Secretary. It includes enforceable content about how and when the section applies.

text: [Act No. 10 of 1958, ss. 1, 2 and 3, Act No. 23 of 1960, ss. 2, 3 and 4, Act No. 19 of 2014, s. 6.]
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation of acts and sections, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 12. [Repealed by Act No. 19 of 2014, s. 7.]
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a reference to a repeal and does not establish a legal rule, right, obligation, or process.

text: 13.  Award of compensation to sufferers from misconduct of inhabitants of area declared under section 106 of Cap. 84 (1)  If in any area, in regard to which any declaration issued under section 106 of the National Police Service Act (Cap. 84) is in force, death or grievous harm, or loss of or damage to property has been caused by, or has ensued from, the misconduct of the inhabitants of such area, or of any class or section of such inhabitants, any person who claims to have suffered loss, damage or injury by reason of such misconduct may, within one month from the date of such loss, damage or injury, make an application for compensation to a magistrate appointed under the said section or, where no magistrate has been so appointed, to a magistrate having jurisdiction within the district in which the declared area is situated.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for individuals to claim compensation for losses due to misconduct in a specific area, detailing the conditions and timeframe for making such claims.

text: (2)  Upon receipt of any such claim, the Magistrate may, after such inquiry as he may consider necessary, and whether or not any additional police officers have been stationed in the declared area under section 106 of the National Police Service Act (Cap. 84)— (a) assess the amount of compensation, if any, to be paid to such person or persons as he may determine; (b) determine the manner, and proportions, in which such compensation shall be distributed; (c) assess the proportions in which such compensation shall be paid by the inhabitants of the declared area; and (d) order the payment of such compensation:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process and obligations related to the assessment and distribution of compensation by a Magistrate. It outlines specific actions and decisions that are enforceable.

text: Provided that the Magistrate— (i) shall not make any assessment or order under the provisions of this subsection, unless he is of opinion that such loss, damage or injury has arisen from a riot or an unlawful assembly within the declared area, and that the person who suffered such loss, damage or injury was himself free from blame in respect of the events which led to such loss, damage or injury; and (ii) shall, in making any assessment under paragraph (c) of this subsection, have regard to the means of the persons ordered to pay compensation.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes specific conditions and obligations for a Magistrate when making assessments or orders related to loss, damage, or injury arising from a riot or unlawful assembly. It includes enforceable content regarding the Magistrate's opinion and considerations for compensation.

text: (3)  Before holding any inquiry under subsection (2) of this section, the Magistrate shall give notice, either generally with reference to the declared area or particularly with reference to any specified premises, property or person, stating— (a) the time and place at which he proposes to hold his inquiry; and (b) the manner in which any claims for compensation, and any objections thereto and to the payment of compensation, shall be presented to him.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation for the Magistrate to provide notice before holding an inquiry, detailing specific requirements for the notice, including time, place, and manner of presenting claims and objections.

text: (4)  The provisions of sections 9, 10 and 16 of the Commissions of Inquiry Act (Cap. 102) shall apply to the Magistrate and any inquiry held by him in pursuance of this section, as if he had been appointed a commissioner under that Act.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes how specific sections of another Act apply to the Magistrate and inquiries, indicating a legal rule or process.

text: (5)  All moneys payable under this section shall be recoverable in the manner provided for the recovery of compensation by sections 173, 334 and 335 of the Criminal Procedure Code (Cap. 75).
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for recovering money, referencing specific sections of the Criminal Procedure Code, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: (6)  If in any civil suit it is proved to the satisfaction of the Court that the plaintiff in such suit has accepted in respect of his claim compensation ordered under subsection (2) of this section to be paid to him, the amount of the compensation shall be taken into account to diminish any damages which he would otherwise receive in that suit.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding how compensation accepted by a plaintiff affects the damages awarded in a civil suit.

text: (7)  For the purposes of this section, "inhabitants" means all persons who occupy any building, or part thereof, in the declared area.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph defines a term ('inhabitants') for the purposes of a specific section, which is essential for interpreting and applying the legal rule within that section.

text: [Act No. 53 of 1960, s. 7, Act No. 3 of 1964, s. 3, Act No. 19 of 1964, s. 2, Act No. 19 of 2014, s. 8.]
label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation of amendments and acts, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 14.  Restriction on use of force (1)  Whenever in this Act it is provided that force may be used for any purpose, the degree of force which may be so used shall not be greater than is reasonably necessary for that purpose; whenever the circumstances so permit without gravely jeopardising the safety of persons and without grave risk of uncontrollable disorder, firearms shall not be used unless weapons less likely to cause death have previously been used without achieving the purpose aforesaid; and firearms and other weapons likely to cause death or serious bodily injury shall, if used, be used with all due caution and deliberation, and without recklessness or negligence.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the use of force, specifying conditions and limitations on the use of firearms and other weapons. It contains enforceable content about the degree of force permissible and the caution required.

text: (2)  Nothing in this section shall derogate from the lawful right of any person to use force in the defence of person or property.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the use of force in defense of person or property, making it enforceable content.

text: Where any order, notice or other document is required by or under this Act or any regulations made thereunder to be given to or served on any person, service thereof may be effected either personally on such person or by registered post; and, where the person to be served is a body corporate or a society or other body of persons, service of any such order, notice or document may be effected by serving it personally on any secretary, director or other officer thereof or on any person concerned or acting in the management thereof, or by leaving it or sending it by registered post addressed to the body corporate, society or body of persons at its registered office, or, where there is no registered office, at any place where it carries on business.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal process for serving documents, detailing how service can be effected on individuals and entities, making it enforceable and actionable.

text: 16.  Presumption of authenticity of certificates
label: not_provision
explanation: This appears to be a title or heading, not a standalone legal provision with enforceable content.

text: A certificate under any of the provisions of this Act, purporting to be signed by the Cabinet Secretary or by any other authority specified in that behalf in such provision, shall be presumed, until the contrary is proved, to have been signed by such Cabinet Secretary or other authority.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal presumption regarding the authenticity of a certificate signed by the Cabinet Secretary or another specified authority, making it an enforceable rule.

text: Every person who is guilty of an offence under this Act, or under any regulations made thereunder, in respect of which no special penalty is provided shall be liable to a fine not exceeding fifty thousand shillings or to imprisonment for a term not exceeding six months, or to both such fine and such imprisonment.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the penalties for offenses under the Act, specifying fines and imprisonment terms.

text: [Act No. 53 of 1960, s. 6, Act No. 19 of 2014, s. 9.]
label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation of amendments or sections from acts and does not establish any legal rule or obligation.

text: 18.  Offences by corporations, societies, etc.
label: not_provision
explanation: This is a section heading and does not contain enforceable or actionable content.

text: Where any offence under this Act or under any regulations made thereunder is committed by any company, or other body corporate, or by any society, association or body of persons, every person charged with, or concerned or acting in, the control or management of the affairs or activities of such company, body corporate, society, association or body of persons shall be guilty of that offence and liable to be punished accordingly, unless it is proved by such person that, through no act or omission on his part, he was not aware that the offence was being or was intended or about to be committed, or that he took all reasonable steps to prevent its commission.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal obligation and potential liability for individuals involved in the management of a company or organization if an offense is committed. It also provides a defense if the individual can prove lack of awareness or that they took reasonable steps to prevent the offense.

text: 19. Offences to be cognisable; and consent of Director of Public Prosecutions
label: provision
explanation: The paragraph indicates that certain offences are cognisable and require the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions, establishing a legal rule or process.

text: All offences under this Act shall be cognisable to the police; and, where it is provided in this Act that a prosecution for an offence thereunder shall not be instituted without the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions, a person may be arrested for and charged with such an offence, and may be remanded in custody or on bail, notwithstanding that the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions to the institution of a prosecution for the offence has not been obtained, but no further or other proceedings shall be taken until such consent has been obtained:
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes legal rules regarding the cognisability of offences to the police, the conditions under which a person may be arrested and charged, and the requirement for the Director of Public Prosecutions' consent before further proceedings.

text: Provided that no person shall be arrested for or charged with an offence under section 3 of this Act save with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions first had and obtained.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal requirement that no person can be arrested or charged under a specific section without the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions, making it an enforceable rule.

label: not_provision
explanation: This text is a citation referencing specific acts and sections, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 20.  Proof of instigation, lawful authority or excuse (1)  Where it is an offence for a person to instigate another to do or omit to do any act or thing, it is immaterial whether or not the instigation succeeds in its purpose.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the irrelevance of the success of instigation in determining the commission of an offence.

text: (2)  For the avoidance of doubt, it is hereby declared that the burden of proving lawful or reasonable excuse or lawful authority shall be upon the person alleging the same, and accordingly in any proceedings for an offence under this Act or any regulations made thereunder it shall not be incumbent on the prosecution to prove the lack of any such excuse or authority.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the burden of proof in legal proceedings, specifying that the burden lies with the person alleging an excuse or authority.

text: Notwithstanding anything contained in any other written law, a subordinate court may try any offence under this Act or under any regulations made thereunder and— (a) if presided over by a Senior Resident Magistrate, or by any Resident Magistrate upon whom such power has, by notice in the Gazette, been
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes the jurisdiction and authority of a subordinate court to try offences under the Act, specifying conditions under which certain magistrates can preside. It contains enforceable legal content.

text: conferred, may pass any sentence authorised for such offence other than a sentence of imprisonment for a term exceeding ten years; (b) if presided over by a Resident Magistrate, may pass any such sentence other than a sentence of imprisonment for a term exceeding seven years; and (c) in any other case, may pass any such sentence other than a sentence of imprisonment for a term exceeding five years.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes specific legal rules regarding the sentencing powers of different types of magistrates, detailing the maximum terms of imprisonment they can impose. It is enforceable and actionable.

label: not_provision
explanation: This is a citation of amendments and legal references, not a standalone legal provision.

text: 22.  Regulations (1)  The Cabinet Secretary may make regulations prescribing anything which may be prescribed under this Act, and generally to give effect to the provisions of this Act.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes the authority of the Cabinet Secretary to make regulations, which is an enforceable legal action.

text: (2)  Notwithstanding the provisions of paragraph (e) of section 31 of the Interpretation and General Provisions Act (Cap. 2), regulations under this section may prescribe such penalties as the Cabinet Secretary may think fit for the contravention thereof, not exceeding, however, the penalties specified in section 17 of this Act.
label: provision
explanation: This paragraph establishes a legal rule regarding the prescription of penalties for contraventions, specifying the authority and limitations on penalties.
